Headline.Para: Fallout from Facebook privacy scandal only just beginning

LeadPara.Para: Cambridge Analytica probe sparks debate on misuse of data and voter manipulation

The British authorities on Friday raided the London offices of Cambridge Analytica, sweeping it for evidence that could implicate the scandal-hit communications company in illegal data mining on Facebook to influence voters in political campaigns.

TailParas.Para: The move is the latest in a slew of investigations across Britain, the United States, the European Union and Australia, sparked by revelations of the misuse of personal information of more than 50 million Facebook users, capping a week of turmoil for both the consulting firm and the social media giant.

Just last week, most of the world had never heard of Cambridge Analytica, the company that purportedly helped real estate tycoon Donald Trump win the data war and delivered him into the White House last year. But this British political consultancy has, in a matter of days, managed to send Facebook stocks tumbling, plunge the social network into its worst crisis, and give the world an education on election propaganda and voter manipulation in the digital age.
It now wallows in the ignominy of multiple probes, amid a raging debate over how data is mined, and how voters are influenced unknowingly.

The maelstrom started on March 17 when The New York Times and Britain's The Observer trotted out a whistle-blower, former employee Christopher Wylie, who exposed Cambridge Analytica for harvesting the private information of tens of millions of Facebook users without their permission.
The end goal for the company was to, among other things, sway the electorate in polls such as the US presidential election in 2016 and the Brexit referendum.

The way it did that was to use the data that it had scraped on Facebook, combined with a psychological model it had developed that could, in Cambridge Analytica CEO Alexander Nix's words, "determine the personality of every single adult in the United States of America".

As Mr Wylie, 28, had described it to The Observer: "We would know what kinds of messaging you'd be susceptible to, including the framing of it, the topics, the contents, the tone. And where you're going to consume that. And then how many times we need to touch you with that in order to change how you think about something."
CUSTOMISING THE NARRATIVE

Instead of standing in the public square and saying what you think and letting people come and listen to you and have that shared experience of what your narrative is, you're whispering into the ear of each and every voter, and you may be whispering one thing to this voter and another thing to another voter.

WHISTLE-BLOWER CHRISTOPHER WYLIE, who exposed his former employer Cambridge Analytica for mining the personal data of over 50 million Facebook users without their knowledge to target political messaging.

The back door to the data leak - the most serious in Facebook's history - came in the shape of a personality quiz app that gathered information on not just Facebook users who took part in the quiz, but also all their friends on the social network.

It was developed by Cambridge University researcher Aleksandr Kogan, who passed the dataset he collected to Cambridge Analytica, which went on a targeting exercise of the American electorate that it later claimed helped Mr Trump clinch the presidency.

Cambridge Analytica had not just data scientists, but also a team of designers, videographers and photographers whose job was to create the propaganda content that its targeting team would "inject into the Internet", said Mr Wylie, a Canadian data scientist who helped found the company.

"Websites and blogs will be created. Whatever it is we think this target profile would be receptive to, we would create content on the Internet for them to find. And they see that, they click it and they go down the rabbit hole," he said to The Observer.

Mr Wylie's revelation was just the first domino to fall, setting off a chain reaction that embroiled Cambridge Analytica in deeper controversy and pushed Facebook into a corner until the social network's founder Mark Zuckerberg finally broke his silence on Wednesday, apologising for not protecting users' data and vowing to change the way it shares information with third-party apps.
By then, billions of dollars had been wiped off Facebook's market value while investors filed a lawsuit after suffering losses from Facebook's mishandling of its users' data.
Related Story
Facebook privacy scandal: A wake-up call for social media users
Related Story
Protecting your personal data from abuse

A #deletefacebook movement also quickly gained momentum after WhatsApp founder Brian Acton, who sold his messenger start-up to Mr Zuckerberg for US$19 billion (S$25 billion) in 2014 , took to Twitter on Wednesday asking people to leave the social network.
The latest convert - tech titan Elon Musk, who on Friday took down two of his company's Facebook pages SpaceX and Tesla.

Meanwhile, US lawmakers are not relenting, formally requesting on Friday that Mr Zuckerberg appear before Congress in a hearing over the data breach and putting the social network's sloppy data-sharing practices under scrutiny.

Early on in the week, Facebook had pointed the finger at Cambridge Analytica and Dr Kogan, accusing the latter of collecting the data under the guise of academic research but later using it for commercial purposes. But up until 2015, Facebook was allowing app developers to help themselves to vast amounts of data on its users as well as their friends, and critics have now warned that Cambridge Analytica is not the only one with heaps of personal information sitting in its servers.

While the scandal is forcing legislators and the tech industry to rethink how they collect and use consumers' personal data, it has at the same time raised questions over the insidious practice of voter manipulation in elections.

Cambridge Analytica was set up primarily for this purpose, after far-right Breitbart News' Steve Bannon heard about the work of a British company called Strategic Communication Laboratories Group (SCL), which did political messaging for foreign governments.

In 2013, Mr Bannon brought on conservative American billionaire Robert Mercer, who pumped US$15 million into a new joint venture with SCL which Mr Bannon named Cambridge Analytica. The goal was to harness online personal data and build detailed psychological profiles, so that messages could be customised to micro-target this audience and shape their political views.

In secretly recorded videos released by Britain's Channel 4 News last week, Cambridge Analytica's Mr Nix was seen bragging about running Mr Trump's entire digital campaign during the presidential election. In the sting operation, in which an undercover journalist posed as a potential client, Mr Nix was also seen proposing honey traps to ensnare his clients' political opponents, or offering bribes to candidates while secretly filming them.
Another Cambridge Analytica executive, Mr Mark Turnbull, was caught on camera boasting that the firm had come up with the "Defeat Crooked Hillary" campaign and pushed it out on social media.
"We just put information into the bloodstream of the Internet and then watch it grow, give it a little push every now and again over time to watch it take shape," he said.

Mr Robert Mueller, the special counsel investigating possible Russian interference in the US election, is already on to Cambridge Analytica, which the Trump campaign hired in June 2016, although it said it did not use Cambridge's data.
Meanwhile, a second whistleblower came forward on Friday, claiming that Cambridge Analytica lied about not doing work for the Leave.EU campaign when it actually did.

Ms Brittany Kaiser, 30, who up until two weeks ago was Cambridge Analytica's business development director, told The Guardian newspaper that the company had used information provided by the Eurosceptic UK Independence Party, although it was not paid for crunching the data.
The unravelling has only just begun.

Article.Art: Officers from the Information Commissioner's Office leaving with a van believed to be carrying evidence after a search of the Cambridge Analytica headquarters in London on Friday.
